title-group.article-title: How Could Something So Right Be So Wrong? OT References to the Left and Right Hand
title-group.subtitle: Implications for Translation in Africa1

contrib.aff: United Bible Societies, Faculté de Théologie Evangélique Alliance Chrétienne, Abidjan

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: Papers in honour of Roger Omanson, Part I

abstract.p: Cross-culturally the left hand is considered the lesser member of the right-left pair, giving rise to right- and left-based linguistic expressions favoring the right hand. In West Africa, left-handedness has positive and negative connotations: while often evoking virility and military prowess, it also connotes impurity, weakness, awkwardness, and sometimes stupidity. After exploring literal and figurative uses of the right and left in the OT, we ask, How does/can an African audience interpret the favoring of the right hand in biblical texts? What are possible readings of the left-handed Benjaminites in the Book of Judges? What are the implications for translation and translator helps?

kwd-group.kwd: right and left in the Bible

body.p: It is well known that the human species is asymmetric, with specializations of the right and left cerebral hemispheres resulting in right- and left-handedness. Many scientists link this universal phenomenon to the emergence of the human race, with left–right differentiation distinguishing homo erectus from homo sapiens, and homo sapiens from other mammals. While some researchers claim left-handedness is currently on the rise,2 most believe that percentages of right- and left-hand use have remained constant since the stone age (Klass 2011):3 90 percent of the population is right-handed, 10 percent, left (Foley 1977). While a gene has been linked to left-handedness,4 the majority of scholars admit that no one really knows why individuals are born one way or the other.

Right- and left-handedness are linked to another interesting phenomenon: in most cultures, right-handedness carries a positive connotation and left-handedness a negative one. Without a doubt, in Scripture, “the right hand” is the place of favor, power, and strength. By default, the left hand is either neutral or viewed in a more negative light. Indeed, throughout history and around the world, being left-handed is often associated with abnormality, criminality, violence, and in some places, with witchcraft and the devil!5 Because of these negative connotations, many societies regularly attempt to impose right-handedness on left-handers. This may go from forcing left-handed school children to use their right hand,6 to beating left-handers with sticks, tying the left hand behind the back, or, in some parts of Africa, actually inflicting wounds on the left hand to prevent its use.7

Despite the persistence of these traditional beliefs, research reveals that left- and right-handers show no difference in IQ, and there is certainly no proof that the left-handed minority is morally inferior to the right-handed majority. Today researchers coming to the defense of left-handers underline the fact that left-handers are often gifted athletes, citing baseball heroes such as Babe Ruth, and “southpaw” boxers, along with left-handed swimming, fencing, and tennis champs. Some note left-handers are independent by nature, creative thinkers, and powerful leaders, citing Julius Caesar, Michelangelo, Leonardo da Vinci, along with Bill Clinton and Barak Obama!

How does the Bible, especially the Old Testament, treat left-handedness? How do current cultures view this feature? And how does this component of worldview interact with Bible translation? Does it affect our view of Scripture, the translation itself, its comprehension and acceptance among readers and hearers?

sec.title: The Stigma of the Left Hand
sec.p: In most cultures across Western and Central Africa, the right hand is favored, while the left hand is considered of lesser status. From Dakar to Kinshasa, eating, gesturing, or pointing with the left hand is forbidden, being considered extremely impolite or even a sign of insult. For example, in the northern Songhai and Hausa cultures (Niger), to name only two, objects must be offered and accepted by the right hand only. Throughout this region, no one shakes with the left hand. If the right hand is dirty or occupied, one rather extends the right arm for a “shake” or greeting.8 For Lingala speakers (DRC), being served or greeted by the left hand could be an evil omen: a sign something bad could happen that day.

Popular wisdom has it that the left hand is impure because it is used to carry out “dirty” activities (toilet, feminine hygiene, wiping babies, etc.). While some might link such attribution to Muslim beliefs, the left-hand stigma is present even in cultures with little or no Muslim influence. In the Bete culture of Côte d’Ivoire, for instance, no woman would dare to cook with her left hand: the food would be inedible. In a church service, a gesture with the left hand by a priest or pastor might cause parishioners to get up and leave! According to traditional Bete beliefs, persons using the left hand in gesture call down a curse upon themselves.9 Among the Didas (Côte d’Ivoire), pointing to one’s village with the left hand means one has no respect for one’s birthplace. Among the Gangam (Togo), to kick a child with the left foot is a particular sign of disdain.

The right/left-hand distinction governs numerous beliefs, customs, and practices worldwide. In several West African cultures, left-handedness is associated with dexterity, prowess, and virility. In Gbaya (Cameroon), a proverb claims “the left hand never misses.” In Baatonum culture (Benin), a left-handed man is considered skillful and brave. People respect but also fear him, because he might have special occult powers. He is also unpredictable: no one ever knows which hand he will use. But despite this semi-special status, the Baatonu left-hander can never become a chief or king because he is not “pure”: he belongs to the category of the “infirm” (blind, lepers, a child born after twins, etc.). He has a spirit of war and thus is thought not to be a reliable leader.

In Gurmanche culture (Burkina Faso), left-handedness is also associated with virility, and extends into the domain of lovemaking. It is the left hand that is the favored hand in moments of intimacy, the hand used to caress one’s wife. To this day, in many villages, men are buried on their right side, with their face turned to the east, so they can—still in death—continue to reach out and caress their wife! Similarly in Nyarafolo culture (Côte d’Ivoire), people are buried on their left side, so the right hand is free to bless and not curse. In other cultures, the left and right also play a significant role in burial customs. For example, in northern Togo, among the Gangam peoples, one never sits on the left side of a house, since this place is reserved during funerals for the body of the deceased. Especially in cases of “bad death,”10 gravediggers are to touch the body only with the left foot. In ritual contexts, that is, the offering of traditional sacrifices, the offering must often be made only by the right hand. In Musgum culture (Cameroon), a left-handed person cannot carry out a sacrifice. Transfer of authority among this same ethnic group is also “hand-sensitive,” carried out by placing the right hand on the person’s head or pointing with the right to this person. Other ritual acts such as blessing and taking an oath also must be carried out by the right hand (Assinga 2007, 71–72, 75).

sec.title: Language and the Left Hand
sec.p: Cultural views on the left hand often significantly impact language forms and use. For example, the very names used to refer to the left and right hand may reflect their status. In Lingala (DRC), the left hand is known as the “hand of the female,” while in Yaka (also DRC), one speaks of the “hand of the father” (right) and “the hand of the mother” (left). These associations are very common throughout west and central Africa. In Musgum (Cameroon) there is not even a word for “right”: “right hand” is tin a wus “hand of man,” also known as “the good hand,” or simply “the hand,” while the left is “the hand of the woman,” the “bad,” or even “the inside-out hand” (Assinga 2007, 64–65)!11 In Bete, the right hand is also associated with maleness and the left with femaleness (being the weaker of the two), though in this language the right hand is formally called “hand with which one eats,” and the left, simply “the left hand.”

Beliefs concerning the left hand impact the creation of idioms and euphemisms. In Baatonum, “to put the left hand” is a euphemism for requesting sex. Thus, to say “She put her left hand on me, but I refused” means “She wanted to make love, but I said no.” In Gurmanche, mentioned above, a man who is constantly running after other women will be labeled (pejoratively) “the one whose left (hand) is leading.”

More frequently, reference to the left evokes very negative behavior or personality traits. In Bete, for example, saying “you are left” or “you have a left hand” means you are out of line or not addressing a situation correctly. In Ngambai (Chad), “Are you left-handed?” is a serious reprimand. The left hand is often associated with a lack of ability to reason, as reflected in the Ngambai proverb, “It is better to have to do with a drunk than with a left-handed person.” In Lele (Chad), “his word is left” means the person is not making sense. Left can also mean “wrong.” In Kisie culture (Guinea), if a child puts her left hand in the cooking, her mother might say, “you’re working with your foot” or “take your foot out of the pot.”

This same linguistic phenomenon is of course present outside Africa. In English, for example, awkward behavior is called “gauche” (a word borrowed from French meaning “left”). A person who is bumbling may be described as “having two left feet.” In contrast, in many languages worldwide, it is the “right” side that is positive, indicating correctness, properness: “You’re right!” “That’s the right answer.” “He’s the right man for the job.” And so on. In many languages, right is also the unmarked element of the right–left word pair, with the right–left order being used when citing examples.

sec.title: The Right and the Left Hand in Biblical Literature
sec.p:
In the Hebrew Bible (as well as in the later intertestamental and New Testament periods), references to right and left are common. In the Old Testament, the Hebrew words for right (yāmîn) and left (śĕmō’l), often cited together, can be understood quite literally, designating the physical right and left. In such contexts, both words appear to be completely neutral in meaning:12
The Israelites went into the sea on dry ground, the waters forming a wall for them on their right and on their left. (Exod 14.22)
Then Samson reached toward the two central pillars on which the temple stood. Bracing himself against them, his right hand on the one and his left hand on the other. (Judg 16.29)
Now all the people and all the warriors were on his [King David’s] right and on his left. (2 Sam 16.6)13

The Hebrew terms are regularly used to indicate cardinal directions, with right indicating the south and left the north, a phenomenon also found in other cultures and languages:15
Your elder sister is Samaria, who lived with her daughters to the north [left] of you; and your younger sister, who lived to the south [right] of you. (Ezek 16.46)

But the pair is also used as a merism, meaning “everywhere”:16
For you will spread out to the right and to the left,
and your descendants will possess the nations
and will settle the desolate towns. (Isa 54.3)17

This word pair is also part of a common idiomatic expression in Hebrew, “not turning to the right hand or the left,” meaning “to go straight ahead”:
[we will not turn] aside to the right hand or to the left until we have passed through your territory. (Num 20.17)18

More often this expression constitutes a powerful metaphor for obedience, that is, listening to, choosing, and doing the right thing. In the Hebrew Bible, this includes obedience to Yahweh and his commands or obedience to the words of a superior, for example, a king:19
You must therefore be careful to do as the Lord your God has commanded you; you shall not turn to the right or to the left. (Deut 5.32)
Only be strong and very courageous, being careful to act in accordance with all the law that my servant Moses commanded you; do not turn from it to the right hand or to the left, so that you may be successful wherever you go. (Josh 1.6)
The king said, “Is the hand of Joab with you in all this?” The woman answered and said, “As surely as you live, my lord the king, one cannot turn right or left from anything that my lord the king has said.” (2 Sam 14.19)

While these examples show that left and right can have a more neutral reading, it is important to note that in the Hebrew Bible, references to the right far outnumber those to the left, and when appearing alone, the right has very positive connotations.

sec.title: Ritual Use of the Right Hand
sec.p:
In legal texts (Exodus and Leviticus) purification rituals involve the right side of the body:
and you shall slaughter the ram, and take some of its blood and put it on the lobe of Aaron’s right ear and on the lobes of the right ears of his sons, and on the thumbs of their right hands, and on the big toes of their right feet, and dash the rest of the blood against all sides of the altar. (Exod 29.20)20

Similar examples occur throughout Leviticus (7.32–33;21 8.23, 24, 31), especially in ch. 14. In some instances both hands are implicated in rituals, but it is always the right hand which is favored and more active than the passive left:
[The priest will] dip his right finger in the oil that is in his left hand and sprinkle some oil with his [right] finger seven times before the Lord. (Lev 14.16)

sec.title: Right as the Place of Honor and Strength
sec.p: Several scholars suggest that the predominance and special connotations of the right in the Hebrew Bible and in Israelite culture may be due to the influence of neighboring cultures. This is confirmed by artifacts found in ancient Asia Minor. For example, in a limestone relief from Iraq dating from 858–824 B.C.E., an Assyrian king extends his right hand to another king, symbolizing a formal agreement. In a set of Egyptian statues dating from 1345–1318 B.C.E., a pharaoh is portrayed as sitting at the right hand of the god Horus (Schroer and Staubli 2001, 151, 161).22 Baal is often portrayed as raising his right hand in a sign of power and victory, with his right also being a place of honor (Assinga 2007, 6). It is thus likely that these peoples influenced the Israelites, but it is also possible that favoring the right hand is simply a general, regional, or near-universal feature reflecting biological realities.

Whatever the origin of this semantic correlation, we know that from the earliest times, the Israelites referred to and praised the right hand of Yahweh. In the Song of the Sea, held to be one of the oldest poetic biblical texts, we read,
Your right hand, O Lord, glorious in power—
your right hand, O Lord, shattered the enemy. (Exod 15.6)23

In later songs, as well, the Lord’s right hand or arm is extolled.24 It is especially associated with Yahweh’s power and strength leading to deliverance and great victories over various enemies:25
You have a mighty arm; strong is your hand,
high your right hand. (Ps 89.14)
Your hand will find out all your enemies;
your right hand will find out those who hate you. (Ps 21.9)
For not by their own sword did they win the land,
nor did their own arm give them victory;
but your right hand, and your arm,
and the light of your countenance, for you delighted in them. (Ps 45.5)
Now I know that the Lord will help his anointed;
he will answer him from his holy heaven
with mighty victories by his right hand. (Ps 20.7)

The right side is also the place of blessing and honor,26 offered to those whom the Lord favors:
You show me the path of life.
In your presence there is fullness of joy;
in your right hand are pleasures forevermore. (Ps 16.11)
The [Lord] said to my Lord, “Sit at my right side,
until I make your enemies into a footstool for you.” (Ps 110.1)27

The right side is a place of protection as well, where believers seek and find refuge:
Wondrously show your steadfast love,
O savior of those who seek refuge from their adversaries
at your right hand. (Ps 17.7)
You have given me the shield of your salvation,
and your right hand has supported me;
your help has made me great. (Ps 18.36)

In an interesting twist, it is Yahweh himself who at times stands at the right of human beings (King David and other followers), where he provides protection, stability, and deliverance from enemies:
I keep the Lord always before me;
because he is at my right hand,
I shall not be moved. (Ps 16.8)
For he stands at the right hand of the needy,
to save them from those who would condemn them to death. (Ps 109.31)
The Lord is at your right hand;
he will shatter kings on the day of his wrath. (Ps 110.5)

However, this position of force and prominence is not restricted to Yahweh. The right is cited in other poetic contexts as the place of activity and source of strength of evil men, even of Satan (Assinga 2007, 18):
Do not sweep me away with sinners,
nor my life with the bloodthirsty,
those in whose hands are evil devices,
and whose right hands are full of bribes. (Ps 26.9–10)
Then he showed me the high priest Joshua standing
before the angel of the Lord,
and Satan standing at his right hand to accuse him. (Zech 3.1)28

Another right-hand scenario involves the swearing of oaths. While there is at least one instance of a two-handed oath (Dan 12.7), most often it is the right hand which is associated with making a solemn promise:29
The Lord has sworn by his right hand and by his mighty arm: “Never again will I . . . (Isa 62.8)

Thus the right hand in Scripture emerges by sheer frequency of appearance and by its many occurrences in contexts of favor, power, and honor, as the positive member of the right–left word pair. As noted by Schroer and Staubli (2001, 160), no direct mention is ever made of God’s left hand.30 And in at least one instance in the Old Testament, the left is directly associated with folly:
The heart of the wise inclines to the right,
but the heart of a fool to the left. (Eccl 10.2)

By default, then, the left is imbued, at best, with lower status and, at worst, with extremely negative connotations. Coming back to the literal or physical meaning of right and left, note that when Joseph brings his children to Jacob for a blessing (Gen 48.13–14), though both hands are used to bless, the right hand carries the higher blessing. The narrator uses careful chiastic structuring to underline the fact that despite Joseph’s attempts to help his father perform the blessing in the proper way, Jacob seemingly intentionally places his right hand of blessing on the younger of the two, rather than the elder:
And Joseph took both of them
Ephraim in his right on Israel’s left
And Manasseh in his left on Israel’s right.
And he brought [them] to him.
And Israel stretched out
his right and put [it] on the head of Ephraim and he was the younger
And his left on the head of Manasseh
He crossed his hands
though Manasseh was the firstborn.

Another context where the right seems preferred over the left is in lovemaking (contrary to the African practice noted above). In the Song of Songs, the following lines form a kind of inclusio, appearing in the beginning and ending sections of the book (2.6; 8.3):
O that his left hand were under my head,
and that his right hand embraced me!31

While both references are positive, we recognize the characteristic active–right and passive–left associations seen above in legal texts. Is it going too far to imagine the caresses are coming from the favored or even pure hand?

sec.title: Special Focus on the Left Hand
sec.p:
There are not many instances of the left hand appearing alone in Scripture, but the most important and intriguing example comes from the book of Judges. This book has been redacted in a most astounding way (Arnold 1995), with several leitmotifs occurring throughout the book. One motif is “hand” which occurs around ninety times, and another, occurring far less frequently, is “left” (Zogbo 2003). The latter clearly occurs at key points in the narrative, where the left hand is explicitly or implicitly mentioned: Ehud’s left-handed victory over Eglon (3.15, 21), Gideon’s attack on the Midianites (7.20), and Samson’s suicide-victory (16.29).32 More significantly, there are two passages forming a kind of inclusio around the book (occurring towards the beginning and at the end) where the words “right” and “left” create a kind of “zone of turbulence,”33 that is, a specially highlighted and or marked account (Zogbo 2003):
Ehud the left-handed warrior (3.15–25)

disp-quote.p: The LORD raised up for them a deliverer, Ehud son of Gera, the Benjaminite [son of right hand], a left-handed man [man bound of right hand]. The Israelites [sons of Israel] sent tribute by him [by his hand] to King Eglon of Moab. Ehud made for himself a sword with two edges, a cubit in length; and he fastened it on his right thigh under his clothes. Then he presented the tribute to King Eglon of Moab. Now Eglon was a very fat man. When Ehud had finished presenting the tribute, he sent the people who carried the tribute on their way. . . . Ehud came to him, while he was sitting alone in his cool roof chamber, and said, “I have a message from God for you.” So he rose from his seat. Then Ehud reached with his left hand, took the sword from his right thigh, and thrust it into Eglon’s belly; the hilt also went in after the blade, and the fat closed over the blade, for he did not draw the sword out of his belly; and the dirt came out. Then Ehud went out into the vestibule and closed the doors of the roof chamber on him, and locked them.

After he had gone, the servants came. When they saw that the doors of the roof chamber were locked, they thought, “He must be relieving himself in the cool chamber.” So they waited until they were embarrassed [Heb.: “until shame”]. When he still did not open the doors of the roof chamber, they took the key and opened them. There was their lord lying dead on the floor.34

list-item.p: Civil war: left-handed Benjaminites against Israelites (20.12–17)

disp-quote.p: The tribes of Israel sent men through all the tribe of Benjamin [son of right], saying, “What crime is this that has been committed among you? Now then, hand over those scoundrels in Gibeah, so that we may put them to death, and purge the evil from Israel.” But the Benjaminites [sons of son of right] would not listen to their kinsfolk [Heb.: “brothers”], the Israelites. The Benjaminites [sons of son of right] came together out of the towns to Gibeah, to go out to battle against the Israelites. On that day the Benjaminites [sons of son of right] mustered twenty-six thousand armed men from their towns, besides the inhabitants of Gibeah. Of all this force, there were seven hundred picked [chosen 2x] men who were left-handed [bound of the right hand]; every one could sling a stone at a hair, and not miss. And the Israelites [men of Israel], apart from Benjamin [son of right], mustered four hundred thousand armed men, all of them warriors.

sec.p: While these passages make it clear that in biblical literature, left-handedness and/or ambidexterity is associated with military prowess and skill,35 there is clearly more behind these words. The zones of turbulence created by repeated themes (“hand,” “bound by/of the right hand,” “right,” “left,” “son,” “sons of son of right,” “chosen”) express biting irony36 as these “sons of the right” refuse to do what is right.

sec.title: Implications for Exegesis, Translation, Scripture Reception, and Translation Helps
sec.p: This study raises a number of issues which touch on how exegesis is done, what translators bring to the text prior to translation, and how translations are interpreted. It also leads us to ideas about how to create better translation helps.

First of all, our study shows that non-Western readers and translators can contribute in a unique and original way to the exegesis of biblical texts. Looking at the Ehud episode through non-Western eyes offers important complementary interpretations. In this passage, African readings underline not only the obvious military prowess associated with the left hand, but link the text to the notion of pure and impure. Clearly, the “juicy bits” of the story of Ehud will be far more accessible to a West or Central African reader than to a European or American one. Besides the turbulence created by the right–left wordplay (at times available only to those with access to the Hebrew), the text creates a humorous “toilet scene” with the fat “calf” King Eglon,37 stabbed in the belly by an unclean (impure) left hand, and his excrement spilling out. His servants think he is indisposed (in the restroom), while in fact, he lies dead, sprawled on the floor. What better way for Israelites to ridicule an impure pagan king?

Surely this background understanding can be carried over to one of the final scenes of Judges, where “sons of son of right” use their left-handed skill to kill their own brethren. Is the narrator not using all means at his disposal (wordplay, repetition, alliteration,38 cultural background) to show the epitome of horror now taking place in Israel? From episodes of victory described in the beginning of the book, Israel now has descended into the pit of utter chaos and civil war. The prominence of the “left” (referred to figuratively in both cases as “tied” or “impeded of the right hand) in these two highly dramatic episodes is a key rhetorical device which contributes to the meaning and tone of the text, a fact that should somehow be highlighted in the translation (or in some kind of note).

Given that some translators come to the text with insights a Western mind cannot provide, we wonder about methods (past and future) used in the creation of translation helps. Would it not be helpful to seek out non-Western wisdom,39 that is, to allow a larger circle of contributors, in both biblical exegesis and discussion of translation issues?

Whatever form translation helps may take (wiki or printed, access through paratext or through published books), it also seems very clear that there is no need to treat the same exegetical and translation issues over and over in multiple places, as in the past.40 In the case of the left and the right, what is called for is a general “help,” covering the subject of right and left. The users of Bible translation helps could easily click first on a global explanation of right and left, and then, as needed, on individual books and individual verses for more precise information.41

There will of course be a need for more localized helps, dealing with specific translation issues.42 In the case of the translation of left and right in Musgum (Cameroon), though these concepts have similar connotations to those outlined above, many biblical passages with “right hand” rendered literally are barely understood! In this language group, being “next to” or “on the side of the chief” is a far more powerful way to express the meaning behind a literal “at the right hand” (Assinga 2007, 91, 95).43 How can helps be created so that those with similar problems can read about translation solutions that have worked?

One may be tempted to ask, Is the question of the left and right hand yet another case in which “corrective measures” must be taken?44 This question arises since some suggest that the Bible’s (over)emphasis on “the right hand” has played a role in perpetuating prejudice against left-handers! Would new and more natural renderings help solve the problem? In Jonah 4.11, for example, where Nineveh’s 120,000 inhabitants “don’t know their right from their left,” CEV ends up saying these people “cannot tell right from wrong.” Do such renderings solve, avoid, or rather complicate the problem? Such questions can perhaps only be answered locally, within and by the community for whom the translation is being done.

Although the focus of this study has been the Hebrew Old Testament, it is obvious that many of our observations carry over into the Greek Deuterocanon and New Testament. Given the widespread adoption of Old Testament images in these other parts of Scripture,45 perhaps notes and other types of explanations would be appropriate in published Bibles. Certainly where there is a “cultural match,” more literal renderings will be understood and appreciated and no notes will be required. However, where connotations of the left are less understood, might it not be better to create and include general notes explaining important points of Bible background?

In a project sponsored by the Alliance Biblique de Côte d’Ivoire, we are producing a Baoule study Bible which, in a simple and inexpensive way, adds framed material highlighting shared customs (naming people and places to remember important events or send important messages to the community) and explaining potential clashes of culture and meaning (e.g., the word “rock” immediately evoking fetish worship, instead of God as a place of refuge; Zogbo 2011). It is easy to see how a culturally pertinent frame for right- and left-handedness could be effective in helping readers better pick up on cues and connotations embedded in the text.

It is perhaps time that in our global village we begin to understand that all peoples of all cultures know that other cultures exist and have practices and beliefs different from their own. Should the translation pendulum stay stuck on domesticated renderings, as we cater to those who cannot understand? Or should we give today’s readers the benefit of the doubt, believing they are sophisticated enough to recognize, accept, and even appreciate the foreignness of a text coming from another time and place?

Pakdembè Ntouame (Gangam), Abdoulaye Ouattara (Nyarafolo), Abraham Tankoano (Gulmancema), and Assinga Thomas (Musgum). We found this a fitting topic for our dear friend and colleague Roger Omanson, a left-hander who has done so much to further Bible translation in Africa.
The current rate in Britain is claimed to be 13 percent left-handed men and 11 percent left-handed women (McManus 2004). About 1 percent of the human race is ambidextrous.
These conclusions are drawn from particular features of cave paintings and wear-and-tear on molar remains.

Klass (2011) cites Clyde Francis (2007), showing that possessors of the gene LRRTMI are more likely to be left-handed. Research reveals left-handedness is more common among males. Curiously, some identical twins are born with one being right-handed and the other left-handed, a fact that has yet to be explained.

In several European cultures, the devil and witches are believed to be or are portrayed as left-handed. Devils “bless” with their left hand. Throwing salt over the left shoulder, where evil spirits lurk, is a way to escape evil influence. The practice of wearing the wedding band on the left hand apparently goes back to a Greek and/or Roman belief that such ornaments ward off evil spirits. Note that there are exceptions to left symbolism. In Zuni (American Indian) culture, the left hand is associated with luck, age, and wisdom.

Tankoano reports that today among the Gurmanche peoples (Burkina Faso), it is difficult to find a single older person who writes with the left hand, though among the younger generation, children now write with the left hand.

In Godie culture (Côte d’Ivoire), in the past, the palm of a child’s left palm was subjected to tiny cuts. Crushed chili pepper was placed in the wound and the hand was then bound, forcing the child to use the right hand. Among the Ngambai (Chad) a plaster cast is made out of clay and placed on the left hand, for a similar result.

Among the Lele of Chad, giving an object with the left hand shows the bearer has some evil intent. In Kisei culture, if someone is obliged to give an object with the left hand, rules of politeness oblige the giver to say something equivalent to “pardon” or “excuse me.”
Some say this gesture means your mother will die.
In many West African cultures, there is a distinction between “good death” and “bad death.” Suicide, death in childbirth, and drowning are often considered bad death.
The woman may not bless anyone with a hand gesture. This task is reserved for the man who blesses with “the hand of the man” (Assinga 2007, 73).
Unless marked otherwise all Scripture quotes come from NRSV.

One is tempted to suggest that the marked order left–right may be foreshadowing or associated with some unhappy event, as in the cases cited. This needs further investigation, since counter-examples seem to exist.
In Songhai (Niger), left is north and right is south.
A similar use is attested in Zech 12.6 and in Greek, 1 Macc 6.45, with soldiers killing people “right and left.”
See also Ezek 21.21; Isa 9.19 (where the meaning is literally “left and right” or possibly “everywhere”).
See also Deut 2.27; 1 Sam 6.12; 2 Sam 2.19; Ps 107.7.
See also Deut 17.11, 20; 28.14; Josh 23.6; 2 Kgs 22.2; 2 Chr 34.2; Prov 4.27. In the deuterocanonicals, see 1 Macc 2.22.
A similar practice is noted among the Musgum, where those concerned may be asked to dip their right toe into the blood poured out in sacrifice (Assinga 2007, 72).
René Péter-Contesse and John Ellington (1990) note at this verse “the importance of the right side among the people of Israel.”
See Zogbo 2003.
See also Exod 15.12.

In Hebrew, the form is simply “right,” a very common way to refer to the right hand, arm, or side. Here “hand” is supplied by NRSV, while CEV proposes “arm”: “With the tremendous force of your right arm, our [Lord], you crushed your enemies.” In many African languages, a single word designates both “arm” and “hand.” Note that in this song, the Hebrew word “hand” occurs explicitly in Exod 3.20, and “arm” in 15.16.

In the Deuterocanon, God strengthens David’s right hand, enabling him to defeat the enemy (Sir 47.5). Note also when the Jews defeat Nicanor, they cut off his head and “his right hand that he had so arrogantly stretched out” (1 Macc 7.47).

In Sirach, learning is like a chain (manacle) on the right hand of a fool, but for the wise, like a golden bracelet placed on the right arm (21.19, 21). Compare also Sir 49.11: “How shall we magnify Zerubbabel? He was like a signet ring on the right hand.”
This image is carried over and quoted extensively in the Gospels. See Matt 22.43–44.
See also Ps 109.6.

See also the Greek text of 2 Macc 14.33: “he [Nicanor] stretched out his right hand toward the sanctuary, and swore this oath: ‘If you do not hand Judas over to me as a prisoner, I will level this shrine of God to the ground.’”

However, even if he does not have a left hand per se, he does seem to have a left “side,” a coveted position in the New Testament, as in Matt 20.21–23 and related passages: “And he said to her, ‘What do you want?’ She said to him, ‘Declare that these two sons of mine will sit, one at your right hand and one at your left, in your kingdom.’” Schroer and Staubli (2001, 163) note that in a Syrian wall fresco from 250 B.C.E. two hands appear above biblical scenes, presumably the hands of God. The right points to the Israelites going through the Sea of Reeds, the left to the destruction of the Egyptian army.

The CEV rendering, “Put your left hand under my head and embrace me with your right arm,” seems awkward. While some say “put your arm around my waist” (FC), it is easier to imagine the lover’s hand caressing his lover.
Interestingly, in the Jael episode, the Hebrew text says she “took the tent peg and the hammer in her hand,” with the left being elided and “her hand” designating the right.
Longacre (1985) notes that points of climax and text leading up to story climax are marked by various rhetorical features. Here the repetition of a lexical item and/or theme creates such an effect.

The “right–left” motif ends here but the “hand” motif continues as Ehud later says to the Israelites, “‘Follow after me; for the LORD has given your enemies the Moabites into your hand.’ So they went down after him, and seized the fords of the Jordan against the Moabites, and allowed no one to cross over. At that time they killed about ten thousand of the Moabites, all strong, able-bodied men; no one escaped. So Moab was subdued that day under the hand of Israel. And the land had rest eighty years” (Judg 3.28–30).
See 1 Chr 2.12: “They were archers, [who] could shoot arrows and sling stones with either the right hand or the left; they were Benjaminites, Saul’s kindred.”

It is well known that in Hebrew and many other languages the repetition of a name can signal extreme disdain and is often used to portray the story’s villain (Marchese n.d.; Zogbo 2009 and forthcoming).
The king’s name means “fat calf” (Ogden and Zogbo Forthcoming).
The incredible bĕnê binyāmin, “sons of son of right.”

This is a call for more “out of house” help, as in the recent Spanish handbooks. In the case of French handbooks, we have tried to find African authors who can provide helps from a more localized base.

For over forty years, each handbook has been written by separate authors, meaning each one addresses similar issues, even if some effort has been made over the years to re-use or adapt what is already present (glossary entries, discussions of poetry, names of God, etc.).

In the Song of Songs handbook (Ogden and Zogbo 1998), the following was made explicit: “In many cultures there is an important distinction between the functions of the right and the left hands. The right hand is used for eating, shaking hands, touching, and caressing, while the left hand is reserved for ‘unclean’ tasks. This probably applied in biblical times, so it is only logical that the young man’s left hand is under the woman’s head, while his right hand caresses her. It is important, therefore, to keep this distinction in the translation, especially where the same cultural norms apply.”

It would be interesting, even imperative, to examine, for example, non-Muslim Asian views of left and right. In the literature available to us, the expression “at the right of” does not appear. In one writing (Handful of Leaves 2007) we read, “‘Sit down, Blessed One. This seat has been prepared.’ So the Blessed One sat on the prepared seat. Potthapada, taking a lower seat, sat to one side” (italics mine).

Other adaptations will also need to be made. In Dan 12.7, it would be extremely awkward to say, “he raised his hand of man and his hand of woman to the sky.” A much better solution would be “he raised both hands” (Assinga 2007, 85, 86). Exodus 15.6, “your right (hand/arm),” could not be rendered literally but rather in a way that would omit reference to the “right,” for example “your power.” It may even be necessary to call Benjamin “son of blessing” since “son of right” has no meaning (Assinga 2007, 89, 90).

I am thinking of the downplaying of negative connotations associated with references to the Jews in the Gospel of John or the careful attempts to make neutral or masculine pronouns inclusive of women.

The dominance of the right in the New Testament is seen in the many prophecies attributed to Christ: “But I say to all of you, you will see the Son of Man sitting at the right hand of the Mighty One” (Matt 26.64), as well as in his parable of the sheep and the goats in Matt 25: “Then the king will say to those at his right hand, ‘Come, you that are blessed by my Father, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world’ ... he will say to those at his left hand, ‘You that are accursed, depart from me into the eternal fire prepared for the devil and his angels’.” See also Rev 10.2. The epistles add to our inventory with “giving the right hand of fellowship” (Gal 2.9), a Greek expression somewhat similar to one found frequently in the Deuterocanon: 1 Macc 6.58; 11.50, 62, 66; 13.45, 50; 2 Macc 4.34; 12.11.
